item.title: compare() two tables
item.description: Usage A big chunk of actuarial life consists of comparing stuff. After preparation of assumptions tables and policy data for valuation models, it’s useful to check how they change over a reporting period to understand the magnitude of movements. During the model development, it’s important to understand the impact of each of the components on the final results. The compare() function helps to see the differences of two tables.

item.title: Easily return reference dates
item.description: Installation The functions described in this post are included in the actuaryr package. library("actuaryr") Date reference functions Purpose First and last days of months, quarters and years are of special meaning for business reporting. The business reports are usually created for the last day of some period, like a month or a year. They enclose data for the first day of this period up to the last. If you create your report in the middle of the period, you may need to quickly refer to these dates.

item.title: Why R for Actuaries?
item.description: The actuarial reporting process The process of life insurance actuarial reporting consists of several steps. Various IT tools are used in different areas. The actuarial reporting process can be divided into the following areas: For valuation models, specialized software is used, such as Prophet or RAFM. I don’t think R can easily replace them. Valuation models consist of a vast amount of variables that interact with each other. It’s not comfortable to work with a big amount of interrelated variables in R.
